Lebesgue-Radon-Nikodym derivative, measure theory

Given σ\sigmaσ-finite measures μ1,μ2,ν1,ν2\mu_1, \mu_2, u_1, u_2μ1​,μ2​,ν1​,ν2​ on a measurable space (X,X)\p{X, \mathcal{X}}(X,X), suppose that μ1≪ν1\mu_1 \ll u_1μ1​≪ν1​ and μ2≪ν2\mu_2 \ll u_2μ2​≪ν2​. Prove that the product measures μ1⊗μ2\mu_1 \otimes \mu_2μ1​⊗μ2​ and ν1⊗ν2 u_1 \otimes u_2ν1​⊗ν2​ on (X×X,X⊗X)\p{X imes X, \mathcal{X} \otimes \mathcal{X}}(X×X,X⊗X) satisfy μ1⊗μ2≪ν1⊗ν2\mu_1 \otimes \mu_2 \ll u_1 \otimes u_2μ1​⊗μ2​≪ν1​⊗ν2​ and the Radon-Nikodym derivatives obey

d(μ1⊗μ2)d(ν1⊗ν2)(x,y)=dμ1dν1(x)dμ2dν2(y)\deriv{\p{\mu_1 \otimes \mu_2}}{\p{ u_1 \otimes u_2}}\p{x, y} = \deriv{\mu_1}{ u_1}\p{x} \deriv{\mu_2}{ u_2}\p{y}d(ν1​⊗ν2​)d(μ1​⊗μ2​)​(x,y)=dν1​dμ1​​(x)dν2​dμ2​​(y)

for ν1⊗ν2 u_1 \otimes u_2ν1​⊗ν2​-almost every (x,y)∈X×X\p{x, y} \in X imes X(x,y)∈X×X.
Solution.

Let E∈X⊗XE \in \mathcal{X} \otimes \mathcal{X}E∈X⊗X and suppose (ν1⊗ν2)(E)\p{ u_1 \otimes u_2}\p{E}(ν1​⊗ν2​)(E). Then by Fubini's theorem (all measures are σ\sigmaσ-finite)

(ν1⊗ν2)(E)=∫χE(x,y) dν1(x) dν2(y)=∫ν1(Ey) dν2(y)=0.\p{ u_1 \otimes u_2}\p{E} = \int \chi_E\p{x, y} \,\diff u_1\p{x} \,\diff u_2\p{y} = \int u_1\p{E_y} \,\diff u_2\p{y} = 0.(ν1​⊗ν2​)(E)=∫χE​(x,y)dν1​(x)dν2​(y)=∫ν1​(Ey​)dν2​(y)=0.

where Ey={x∈X∣(x,y)∈E}E_y = \set{x \in X \mid \p{x, y} \in E}Ey​={x∈X∣(x,y)∈E}. Since ν1≥0 u_1 \geq 0ν1​≥0, it follows that ν1(Ey)=0 u_1\p{E_y} = 0ν1​(Ey​)=0 for ν2 u_2ν2​-almost every y∈Xy \in Xy∈X, so by absolute continuity, it follows that μ1(Ey)=0\mu_1\p{E_y} = 0μ1​(Ey​)=0 for ν2 u_2ν2​-almost every y∈Xy \in Xy∈X, and by absolute continuity again,

ν2({y∈X∣μ1(Ey)>0})=0  ⟹  μ2({y∈X∣μ1(Ey)>0})=0, u_2\p{\set{y \in X \mid \mu_1\p{E_y} > 0}} = 0 \implies \mu_2\p{\set{y \in X \mid \mu_1\p{E_y} > 0}} = 0,ν2​({y∈X∣μ1​(Ey​)>0})=0⟹μ2​({y∈X∣μ1​(Ey​)>0})=0,

i.e., μ1(Ey)=0\mu_1\p{E_y} = 0μ1​(Ey​)=0 for μ2\mu_2μ2​-almost every yyy. Hence,

(μ1⊗μ2)(E)=∫χE(x,y) dμ1(x) dμ2(y)=∫μ1(Ey) dμ2(y)=0,\p{\mu_1 \otimes \mu_2}\p{E} = \int \chi_E\p{x, y} \,\diff\mu_1\p{x} \,\diff\mu_2\p{y} = \int \mu_1\p{E_y} \,\diff\mu_2\p{y} = 0,(μ1​⊗μ2​)(E)=∫χE​(x,y)dμ1​(x)dμ2​(y)=∫μ1​(Ey​)dμ2​(y)=0,

so μ1⊗μ2≪ν1⊗ν2\mu_1 \otimes \mu_2 \ll u_1 \otimes u_2μ1​⊗μ2​≪ν1​⊗ν2​. For the second claim, by absolute continuity, we have

d(μ1⊗μ2)=d(μ1⊗μ2)d(ν1⊗ν2) d(ν1⊗ν2),dμ1=dμ1dν1 dν1anddμ2=dμ2dν2 dν2. egin{gathered} \diff\p{\mu_1 \otimes \mu_2} = \deriv{\p{\mu_1 \otimes \mu_2}}{\p{ u_1 \otimes u_2}} \,\diff\p{ u_1 \otimes u_2}, \ \diff\mu_1 = \deriv{\mu_1}{ u_1} \,\diff u_1 \quad ext{and}\quad \diff\mu_2 = \deriv{\mu_2}{ u_2} \,\diff u_2. \end{gathered}d(μ1​⊗μ2​)=d(ν1​⊗ν2​)d(μ1​⊗μ2​)​d(ν1​⊗ν2​),dμ1​=dν1​dμ1​​dν1​anddμ2​=dν2​dμ2​​dν2​.​

Observe that if A×B∈X⊗XA imes B \in \mathcal{X} \otimes \mathcal{X}A×B∈X⊗X,

∫A×Bd(μ1⊗μ2)d(ν1⊗ν2) d(ν1⊗ν2)=(μ1⊗μ2)(A×B)=∫χA×B dμ1 dμ2=(∫Adμ1)(∫Bdμ2)=(∫Adμ1dν1 dν1)(∫Bdμ2dν2 dν2)=∫A×Bdμ1dν1(x)dμ2dν2(y) dν1(x) dν2(y). egin{aligned} \int_{A imes B} \deriv{\p{\mu_1 \otimes \mu_2}}{\p{ u_1 \otimes u_2}} \,\diff\p{ u_1 \otimes u_2} &= \p{\mu_1 \otimes \mu_2}\p{A imes B} \ &= \int \chi_{A imes B} \,\diff\mu_1 \,\diff\mu_2 \ &= \p{\int_A \diff\mu_1}\p{\int_B \diff\mu_2} \ &= \p{\int_A \deriv{\mu_1}{ u_1} \,\diff u_1} \p{\int_B \deriv{\mu_2}{ u_2} \,\diff u_2} \ &= \int_{A imes B} \deriv{\mu_1}{ u_1}\p{x} \deriv{\mu_2}{ u_2}\p{y} \,\diff u_1\p{x} \,\diff u_2\p{y}. \end{aligned}∫A×B​d(ν1​⊗ν2​)d(μ1​⊗μ2​)​d(ν1​⊗ν2​)​=(μ1​⊗μ2​)(A×B)=∫χA×B​dμ1​dμ2​=(∫A​dμ1​)(∫B​dμ2​)=(∫A​dν1​dμ1​​dν1​)(∫B​dν2​dμ2​​dν2​)=∫A×B​dν1​dμ1​​(x)dν2​dμ2​​(y)dν1​(x)dν2​(y).​

It follows that equality holds when we replace A×BA imes BA×B with countable unions of disjoint measurable rectangles. Hence, by Carathéodory's theorem, we see that d(μ1⊗μ2)d(ν1⊗ν2) d(ν1⊗ν2)\deriv{\p{\mu_1 \otimes \mu_2}}{\p{ u_1 \otimes u_2}} \,\diff\p{ u_1 \otimes u_2}d(ν1​⊗ν2​)d(μ1​⊗μ2​)​d(ν1​⊗ν2​) and dμ1dν1(x)dμ2dν2(y) dν1(x) dν2(y)\deriv{\mu_1}{ u_1}\p{x} \deriv{\mu_2}{ u_2}\p{y} \,\diff u_1\p{x} \,\diff u_2\p{y}dν1​dμ1​​(x)dν2​dμ2​​(y)dν1​(x)dν2​(y) agree on all measurable sets. Thus,

d(μ1⊗μ2)d(ν1⊗ν2)(x,y)=dμ1dν1(x)dμ2dν2(y)\deriv{\p{\mu_1 \otimes \mu_2}}{\p{ u_1 \otimes u_2}}\p{x, y} = \deriv{\mu_1}{ u_1}\p{x} \deriv{\mu_2}{ u_2}\p{y}d(ν1​⊗ν2​)d(μ1​⊗μ2​)​(x,y)=dν1​dμ1​​(x)dν2​dμ2​​(y)

ν1⊗ν2 u_1 \otimes u_2ν1​⊗ν2​-almost everywhere.
